tool.name: NDVIBuilding_Filter

param.name: inputdir
param.dialogReference: The directory where the Building Extraction objects are located.

param.name: outputdir
param.dialogReference: The directory where the output building footprints will be placed.

param.name: threshold
param.dialogReference: The standard deviation threshold above which the values will be changed to NoData. Areas of high variation in elevation (standard deviation) are considered to be vegetation, whereas low standard deviation values are more typical of roof tops. The default is 1.5.

param.name: spectral_detail
param.dialogReference: Sets the level of importance given to the spectral differences of features in the imagery. Valid values range from 1.0 to 20.0. A higher value is appropriate when the features are spectrally similar. Smaller values create smoother outputs. If the output scene is too generalized, then raise the value. If it is too segmented then lower the value.

param.name: spatial_detail
param.dialogReference: Sets the level of importance given to the proximity between features in the imagery. Valid values range from 1.0 to 20.0. A higher value is appropriate when the features are spatially interrelated. Smaller values create smoother outputs. If the output scene is too generalized, then raise the value. If it is too segmented then lower the value.

param.name: min_segment_size
param.dialogReference: The minimum size in grid cells that will be considered an object.

param.name: ndvifile
param.dialogReference: The Normalized Difference Vegetation Image (NDVI) created from similar spatial resolution imagery to filter out raster objects which actually may be vegetation. This should be in Imagine .img format.

param.name: ndvithreshold
param.dialogReference: The value of the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) above which will be considered vegetation and assigned to NoData.

param.name: regularizationmethod
param.dialogReference:
The regularization method to be used in processing the input features. This converts the jagged edges of the input polygons into straighter edges more consistent with building footprints. Right Angles are the default regularization method.

  • RIGHT_ANGLES (defualt) - Useful for building footprints that are primarily defined by right angles.

  • RIGHT_ANGLES_AND_DIAGONALS – Useful for buildings footprints that are comprised of right angles and diagonal sides.

  • ANY_ANGLE – Useful for buildings with highly irregular footprints.

  • CIRCLE – Useful for buildings with circular characteristics, like grain silos and water towers.

param.name: tolerance
param.dialogReference: The maximum distance that the regularized footprint can deviate from the boundary of its originating feature. The specified value will be based on the linear units of the input feature’s coordinate system.

param.name: densification
param.dialogReference:
The sampling interval that will be used to evaluate whether the regularized feature will be straight or bent. The densification must be equal to or less than the tolerance value.

This parameter is only used with methods that support right angle identification.

param.name: shapearea
param.displayname: Minimum Building Footprint Area (in map units)
param.dialogReference: The minumum size of the polygon to be considered a building footprint. The units are in square values of the distance units. For example, a value of 32 for a data set measured in meters will filter out polygons smaller than 32 square meters.

tool.summary: This tool creates the building footprints using LiDAR LAS 1.4 tiles. This tool uses the output from the Building Object Extractor tool and then filters these objects using the rooftop height standard deviation and their average NDVI value. The results from these filters are then converted to vector polygons, filtered based on a minimum roof area and the edges cleaned up to create the building footprint polygons.
